content.value_statement: React developers often struggle with proper hooks usage, effect dependencies, and component patterns. This skill provides battle-tested patterns for hooks, effects, refs, and component design to write cleaner, more maintainable React code.
actual_capabilities: Guide proper useEffect patterns including dependencies and cleanup
Identify and fix React anti-patterns in existing code
Recommend when to use refs vs state vs derived values
Provide custom hook design patterns and naming conventions
Explain controlled vs uncontrolled components and composition patterns
limitations: Does not generate React code from scratch
Does not integrate with React build tools or frameworks
Does not execute or test React code

use_cases.title: Refactor legacy React code
use_cases.description: Review React components and identify anti-patterns like effect misuse, missing cleanup, or incorrect ref usage.

use_cases.title: Learn proper hooks patterns
use_cases.description: Understand when and how to use useEffect, useRef, and custom hooks correctly through examples.

use_cases.title: Validate React component patterns
use_cases.description: Ensure pull requests follow React best practices for effects, dependencies, and component composition.

prompt_templates.title: Fix useEffect issues
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this React component and fix any useEffect issues including missing cleanup, incorrect dependencies, or unnecessary effects.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor derived state
prompt_templates.prompt: Identify derived state in this component that should be calculated during render instead of in useEffect.

prompt_templates.title: Design custom hook
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom hook pattern for extracting this logic, following proper naming and sharing state guidelines.

prompt_templates.title: Review ref usage
prompt_templates.prompt: Check this component for incorrect ref.current access during render and recommend proper ref patterns.

output_examples.input: Review this component for React best practice violations
output: useEffect used for derived state - calculate fullName during render instead
Missing cleanup function - add return statement to disconnect WebSocket
Effect depends on object that changes every render - move creation inside effect
Proper useRef usage for non-rendering value
Event handler correctly manages user interaction

output_examples.input: Create a custom hook for form input handling
output: Hook name follows useXxx pattern since it uses React hooks internally
Returns current value and change handler as a tuple
Initial value passed as parameter for flexibility
State managed independently per hook instance

output_examples.input: When should I use useEffect vs useMemo?
output: useEffect is for synchronizing with external systems like subscriptions and event listeners
useMemo is for caching expensive calculations that should not re-run on every render
Use derived state calculated from props during render, not in useEffect
Both require dependency arrays but serve different purposes

best_practices: Calculate derived state during render rather than in useEffect
Always return a cleanup function from effects that set up subscriptions or event listeners
Use updater functions (setState(prev => prev + 1)) to avoid unnecessary dependencies
anti_patterns: Using useEffect to synchronize state that can be calculated from props
Reading or writing ref.current during render

faq.question: Does this skill work with Next.js and Remix?
faq.answer: Yes. The patterns apply to any React framework. Server components follow different rules for effects and state.

faq.question: Does this skill cover React Query or data fetching?
faq.answer: It mentions preferring framework data fetching over manual useEffect fetch patterns. Full React Query guidance requires additional documentation.

faq.question: Should I always use TypeScript with React?
faq.answer: This skill recommends pairing with the TypeScript best practices skill for type safety and better IDE support.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. It provides patterns and guidance. You apply the recommendations to your own code.

faq.question: What React versions are supported?
faq.answer: The patterns target React 18 and 19, including useEffectEvent which requires the latest React canary release.

faq.question: How does this compare to the official React docs?
faq.answer: This skill distills the official docs into actionable patterns for code review and refactoring scenarios.
